Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Situation2: An invited guest speaker has prepared a sermon and can take the pulpit if needed.
Story: This morning, as I was preparing my notes for the Friday sermon, I heard my dog barking loudly in the hallway. I rushed out to find Mrs. Patel, my neighbor, standing by the shared door, her arms full of groceries and her face tight with frustration. She reminded me, not for the first time, that the noise was disturbing her elderly mother. I apologized, feeling the weight of my responsibility as a neighbor to keep the peace and respect our shared spaces. Yet, my mind was already occupied with the mosque’s expectations. Today, I was scheduled to deliver the Khutbah, but the guest speaker was ready and willing to step in if I needed to handle something urgent. I stood in the hallway, torn between calming my neighbor’s concerns and fulfilling my duty as imam. The pressure of both roles pressed in on me, each demanding my presence, each expecting me to do the right thing. My heart pounded as I tried to decide where I was needed most.
